physicalObject: gray and white camouflage wireless game controller
proxyLocation: top left of image 0
utilizationMethod: Wrap your fingers around the left grip so the bulk of the controller sits above the fist, then swing the clenched hand downward as if striking

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: noticable top-heavy feel, overall weight is about 1 kg
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Straight shaft (~3cm thick, ~40 cm long)
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users will clasp the wooden shaft with a full power grip, wrapping all fingers around the ~3 cm-thick handle near its lower third. The dominant hand (or both hands for heavier swings) cocks rearward at the elbow and shoulder, then accelerates forward in an arcing motion to drive the steel head into a target. The top-heavy mass (≈1 kg focused at the head) produces noticeable rotational inertia, so the wrist naturally follows through while the forearm absorbs counter-torque. On impact the virtual hammer stops abruptly, transferring a short, high-frequency vibration down the handle, after which the user either rebounds for another strike or relaxes grip to carry the tool at rest.

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: Users would feel heftier mass concentrated in the hilt (about 500 g), with balanced weight distribution that doesn’t feel front-heavy.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users would overall feel a cylindrical shape while grasping with a diameter about 3cm
virtualObjectInfo.temperature: User would feel the surface cool to touch
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user encloses the cylindrical hilt (≈3 cm diameter) with one or two hands—thumbs forward, fingers curling in a symmetrical power grip similar to a flashlight or fencing weapon. A thumb press or slide of the activation switch precedes motion, after which the user performs broad slashes, diagonal cuts, and thrusts. Because the perceived mass is concentrated in the hilt (≈500 g) and the blade is mass-less light, the saber feels well balanced; inertia is low so direction changes are quick and wrist-driven. When the luminous blade intersects virtual objects it offers minimal resistance (it 'slices' rather than impacts), and a continuous low-frequency hum responds to speed—growing louder during fast swings.

proxyLocation: top left of the black tabletop in Snapshot 1

virtualObjectInfo.inertia: Users should perceive very light overall weight about 10g
virtualObjectInfo.outline: Users’ thumb and index finger sit about 1 cm apart
virtualObjectInfo.hardness: Users should feel soft and elastic feedback while squeezing and releasing
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Held like a pipette between thumb and first two fingers near the rubber bulb, the dropper uses a precision pinch. The thumb pads onto the bulb’s apex while index and middle fingers brace the glass stem. The thumb compresses the elastic rubber 5–10 mm, meeting soft resistance; releasing creates a vacuum that draws liquid up the tube. Users then tilt the wrist over a target and perform gentle repeated squeezes to dispense drops. The bulb quickly regains shape after each press, giving a springy rebound sensation with virtually no inertia due to its ≈10 g mass.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: an interactive creature for petting and combat
virtualObjectInfo.texture: Users should feel dozens of dotted spikes
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Interaction is primarily tactile contact rather than grasping. Users reach out with fingertips or the palm and either stroke, pat, or poke the creature. During combat-style contact, users may slap or punch with an open palm/fist, feeling the same soft give followed by a spring-back recoil.

virtualObjectInfo.texture: User should feel a slick foil like skin
virtualObjectInfo.hardness: Users should feel very soft and compliant surface
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: Users lightly flick, tap, or push the hovering balloon with fingertips, knuckles, or the flat palm. Contact duration is momentary—a quick tap imparts impulse, after which the balloon deforms slightly under the touch (soft compliance, foil-slick skin), then drifts away due to low mass and buoyancy. Because inertia is minimal, even gentle taps induce noticeable displacement, and the surface self-smooths as the balloon returns to its original star shape while floating.
